PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1941, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. No penalty will be imposed if you do not answer all questions.

Remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on this questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

NO. 5

PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

2. How many of these were bachelor's homes?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Once a week.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon, evening.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (times, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Several times and for every visit.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? The whole family always.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. Whenever new buildings were going up for the house.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, once a month, etc.? No.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.
SAINT LOUISAN ANCESTORS QUESTIONNAIRE.

PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

1. In the first years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the corn to make poltuskin used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshments might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the bees were for and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in houses?

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times—every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for communal dances, Christmas tree planting, etc. You have not described these on the School Questionnaire. Give dates.

What material was it made of?

How large was it?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings, did you continue to use example: If you lived in the district, did you come to the local school house for district gatherings and come to the hall in town for other functions? Were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9 and 10) did the entire family attend?

However, babies and small children provided for?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?
